results.title: Pesticides
results.creator_credit: Robert Richter, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Pesticides and pills for export only”.
The film presents evidence that products banned or restricted in developed countries because of their danger to humans or the environment are knowingly exported to the Third World by multinational corporations. This episode investigates the trade in pesticides.

results.title: Peruvian plateau
results.brief_description: How primitive methods of mining and transportation have been replaced by modern methods which have helped to increase the wealth obtained from the Andean peaks and plateau of Peru.

results.title: Peru: the revolution that never was
results.creator_credit: Thames Television, David Elstein and Peter Tiffin
results.brief_description: Shows the abject poverty and miserable life style still endured by Peruvian peasant farmers, and notes how the changes to the land tenure system brought about by the 1968 revolution have failed to bring any change in the deplorable living standards of the Peruvian peasant farmer. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: Peru people of the Andes
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Milan Herzog
results.brief_description: Explores the Chincheros Valley near Cuzco and contrasts the community life in a self contained Indian Village with that of the tenant farmers who work on the haciendas. Illustrates Peru’s recent economic progress as evidenced in the new mining camps, transportation facilities and the wealth which is concentrated in Lima. (Revision of 1940 film, “Peru”.)

results.title: Perth's Mitchell Freeway
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Norman A. Uren
results.brief_description: The application of the Mitchell Freeway plan to Perth, its immediate advantage in handling growing traffic densities and the long term implications of city development, are seen in their close inter-relationships.

results.title: Perth
results.creator_credit: Henry Lewes, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
A pictorial story with minimum commentary on the city of Perth. The daily newspaper is used as the medium to reflect, social, business and sporting activities of the average Australian family living in the city of Perth.

results.title: Persuasion [DVD]
results.creator_credit: BBC, WGBH (Boston), Mobil Masterpiece Theatre, Millesime Productions, Fiona Finlay and Roger Michell
results.brief_description: Originally made as a telemovie but released in cinemas, “Persuasion” is an adaptation of Jane Austen’s last novel about love lost and regained. Amanda Root gives a sensitive performance as Ann Eliot, while Ciaran Hinds is Captain Frederick Wentworth. Eight years prior to the opening of the story, Ann and Wentworth were in love but Ann is persuaded by her family and friend Lady Russell, to abandon the then penniless Wentworth. Time does not alter the depth of her love for him and she is resigned to solitude. Circumstances reunite the couple and this time it is her family who are impecunious and Wentworth who is rich. Can he put aside the bitterness of her rejection and rekindle the flame of their affection?
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC, WGBH (Boston), Mobil Masterpiece Theatre, Millesime Productions, Fiona Finlay and Roger Michell

results.title: Persuasion
results.brief_description: Despite knowing her own heart, Anne Elliot allows herself to be “persuaded” into rejecting the proposal of Captain Wentworth. After an eight year separation, they meet again. Although still eligible and now prosperous, Wentworth is still bitter and courts the attention of Louisa Musgrove. As is typical of all Austen novels, as Anne and Wentworth undertake the road to matrimony, a small section of a long ago society, with its social mores is exposed. Adapted by Julian Mitchell, this BBC production has the flavour of authenticity and features Ann Firbank and Bryan Marshall as the two lovers.
